information_side.text_content: What command shows all running processes?

answer_side.text_content:
ps aux

This shows all processes with detailed information:
- a: show processes for all users
- u: display user-oriented format
- x: include processes not attached to a terminal

Alternatively: ps -ef

information_side.text_content: How do you kill a process by its PID?

answer_side.text_content:
kill PID

Examples:
kill 1234  (terminate process with PID 1234)
kill -9 1234  (force kill with SIGKILL)
kill -15 1234  (graceful termination with SIGTERM)

Use 'ps aux | grep processname' to find the PID first.

information_side.text_content: What command displays real-time system resource usage?

answer_side.text_content:
top

Shows real-time view of:
- CPU usage
- Memory usage
- Running processes
- Load average

Useful keys in top:
q: quit
k: kill process
r: renice process
P: sort by CPU
M: sort by memory

information_side.text_content: How do you check available disk space?

answer_side.text_content:
df -h

Displays disk space usage in human-readable format:
- Shows mounted filesystems
- Available and used space
- Mount points
- Percentage used

For directory usage: du -h /path/to/directory

information_side.text_content: What command shows memory usage?

answer_side.text_content:
free -h

Displays memory usage in human-readable format:
- Total, used, free memory
- Buffer/cache usage
- Swap usage

Alternatively:
cat /proc/meminfo  (detailed memory information)

information_side.text_content: How do you start a service using systemctl?

answer_side.text_content:
systemctl start service_name

Examples:
systemctl start apache2
systemctl start mysql
systemctl start ssh

Other systemctl commands:
stop, restart, reload, enable, disable, status

information_side.text_content: How do you add a new user to the system?

answer_side.text_content:
useradd username

Common options:
useradd -m username  (create home directory)
useradd -s /bin/bash username  (set shell)
useradd -G groupname username  (add to group)

After creation: passwd username (set password)

information_side.text_content: What file contains user account information?

answer_side.text_content:
/etc/passwd

Contains:
- Username
- User ID (UID)
- Group ID (GID)
- Home directory
- Default shell

Format: username:x:UID:GID:comment:home:shell
Password hashes are stored in /etc/shadow

information_side.text_content: How do you view system logs?

answer_side.text_content:
journalctl (systemd systems)

Examples:
journalctl  (all logs)
journalctl -f  (follow logs in real-time)
journalctl -u service_name  (logs for specific service)
journalctl --since today  (today's logs)

Traditional: tail -f /var/log/syslog

information_side.text_content: What command shows who is currently logged in?

answer_side.text_content:
who or w

who: shows logged-in users
w: shows users and what they're doing
whoami: shows current username
last: shows login history
users: simple list of logged-in users

information_side.text_content: How do you manage users and groups in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
User management:
useradd username  (add user)
usermod -aG groupname username  (add user to group)
userdel username  (delete user)
passwd username  (set password)

Group management:
groupadd groupname  (create group)
groupdel groupname  (delete group)
groups username  (show user's groups)
id username  (show user/group IDs)

User info:
cat /etc/passwd  (user accounts)
cat /etc/group  (group information)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system resource monitoring?

answer_side.text_content:
System monitoring commands:

CPU and Memory:
top  (real-time process viewer)
htop  (enhanced top)
free -h  (memory usage)
uptime  (system load)
vmstat 1  (virtual memory stats)

Disk Usage:
df -h  (filesystem usage)
du -sh /path  (directory size)
iostat  (I/O statistics)
lsblk  (block devices)

System Info:
uname -a  (system information)
lscpu  (CPU information)
lsusb  (USB devices)
lspci  (PCI devices)

information_side.text_content: How do you schedule tasks with cron?

answer_side.text_content:
Cron job management:

crontab -e  (edit cron jobs)
crontab -l  (list cron jobs)
crontab -r  (remove all cron jobs)

Cron syntax (minute hour day month weekday command):
0 2 * * * /path/to/script  (daily at 2 AM)
*/15 * * * * /path/to/script  (every 15 minutes)
0 0 1 * * /path/to/script  (monthly on 1st)
0 9 * * 1-5 /path/to/script  (weekdays at 9 AM)

System cron:
/etc/crontab
/etc/cron.d/
/etc/cron.daily/

information_side.text_content: What are the essential log file locations and commands?

answer_side.text_content:
Important log files:
/var/log/syslog  (system messages)
/var/log/auth.log  (authentication)
/var/log/kern.log  (kernel messages)
/var/log/dmesg  (boot messages)
/var/log/messages  (general system)

Log viewing commands:
tail -f /var/log/syslog  (follow log)
head -n 50 /var/log/auth.log  (first 50 lines)
grep "error" /var/log/syslog  (search logs)

Systemd logs:
journalctl -f  (follow journal)
journalctl -u service_name  (service logs)
journalctl --since "1 hour ago"

information_side.text_content: How do you manage disk partitions and filesystems?

answer_side.text_content:
Disk and filesystem management:

Partitioning:
fdisk /dev/sda  (partition disk)
parted /dev/sda  (advanced partitioning)
lsblk  (view block devices)
blkid  (view filesystem UUIDs)

Filesystem operations:
mkfs.ext4 /dev/sda1  (create ext4 filesystem)
mount /dev/sda1 /mnt  (mount filesystem)
umount /mnt  (unmount filesystem)
fsck /dev/sda1  (check filesystem)
resize2fs /dev/sda1  (resize ext filesystem)

Persistent mounting:
/etc/fstab  (filesystem table)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system backup and recovery?

answer_side.text_content:
Backup and recovery tools:

File-level backups:
tar -czf backup.tar.gz /home/user  (create archive)
tar -xzf backup.tar.gz  (extract archive)
rsync -av /source/ /destination/  (sync directories)
dd if=/dev/sda of=backup.img  (disk image)

Advanced backup:
dump -0u -f /backup/home.dump /home  (dump filesystem)
restore -rf /backup/home.dump  (restore dump)
cpio -o < filelist > archive.cpio  (create cpio archive)

Scheduled backups:
crontab with rsync or tar commands

information_side.text_content: How do you manage environment variables and system configuration?

answer_side.text_content:
Environment variables:

View variables:
env  (all environment variables)
echo $PATH  (specific variable)
echo $HOME  (home directory)
printenv USER  (specific variable)

Set variables:
export MYVAR="value"  (temporary)
echo 'export MYVAR="value"' >> ~/.bashrc  (permanent)

System configuration:
/etc/environment  (system-wide variables)
/etc/profile  (system-wide profile)
~/.bashrc  (user shell configuration)
~/.profile  (user login profile)

Reload configuration:
source ~/.bashrc

information_side.text_content: What are the key commands for package management?

answer_side.text_content:
Package management (varies by distribution):

Debian/Ubuntu (apt):
apt update  (update package list)
apt upgrade  (upgrade packages)
apt install package  (install package)
apt remove package  (remove package)
apt search keyword  (search packages)
dpkg -l  (list installed packages)

Red Hat/CentOS (yum/dnf):
yum update  (update packages)
yum install package  (install package)
yum remove package  (remove package)
rpm -qa  (list installed packages)

Universal:
snap install package  (snap packages)
flatpak install package  (flatpak packages)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system startup and boot process?

answer_side.text_content:
Boot and startup management:

Systemd targets:
systemctl get-default  (current default target)
systemctl set-default multi-user.target  (set target)
systemctl isolate graphical.target  (switch target)

Boot process:
dmesg  (kernel boot messages)
journalctl -b  (boot log)
systemctl --failed  (failed services)

GRUB bootloader:
/etc/default/grub  (GRUB configuration)
update-grub  (update GRUB menu)
grub-install /dev/sda  (install GRUB)

Runlevels (legacy):
runlevel  (current runlevel)
init 3  (change to runlevel 3)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system security and access control?

answer_side.text_content:
Security and access control:

Sudo management:
sudo command  (run as root)
sudo -u user command  (run as specific user)
visudo  (edit sudoers file)
sudo -l  (list sudo privileges)

File permissions:
chmod 755 file  (change permissions)
chown user:group file  (change ownership)
umask 022  (set default permissions)
getfacl file  (get ACL)
setfacl -m u:user:rwx file  (set ACL)

Security tools:
last  (login history)
who  (current users)
sudo passwd -l user  (lock user account)
fail2ban  (intrusion prevention)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system performance and optimize resources?

answer_side.text_content:
Performance optimization:

Process priority:
nice -n 10 command  (start with lower priority)
renice -n 5 -p PID  (change process priority)
ionice -c 3 -p PID  (set I/O priority)

System tuning:
sysctl -a  (view all kernel parameters)
echo value > /proc/sys/path  (temporary change)
/etc/sysctl.conf  (permanent kernel tuning)

Memory management:
swapoff -a  (disable swap)
swapon -a  (enable swap)
echo 3 > /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches  (clear cache)

Performance monitoring:
sar -u 1 10  (CPU usage)
sar -r 1 10  (memory usage)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with kernel module management?

answer_side.text_content:
Kernel module management:

Module operations:
lsmod  (list loaded modules)
modprobe module_name  (load module)
modprobe -r module_name  (remove module)
insmod /path/to/module.ko  (insert module)
rmmod module_name  (remove module)

Module information:
modinfo module_name  (module details)
lsmod | grep module_name  (check if loaded)

Module configuration:
/etc/modules  (modules to load at boot)
/etc/modprobe.d/  (module options)
/lib/modules/$(uname -r)/  (module location)

Kernel info:
uname -r  (kernel version)
depmod -a  (update module dependencies)

information_side.text_content: How do you configure and manage swap space?

answer_side.text_content:
Swap space management:

Create swap file:
dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1M count=1024
chmod 600 /swapfile
mkswap /swapfile
swapon /swapfile

Create swap partition:
mkswap /dev/sdb1
swapon /dev/sdb1

Manage swap:
swapon -s  (show swap usage)
swapoff /swapfile  (disable swap)
free -h  (view swap usage)

Persistent swap:
echo '/swapfile none swap sw 0 0' >> /etc/fstab

Swap tuning:
echo 10 > /proc/sys/vm/swappiness  (adjust swap tendency)

information_side.text_content: What are the essential commands for hardware management?

answer_side.text_content:
Hardware management:

Hardware information:
lshw  (detailed hardware info)
lscpu  (CPU information)
lsmem  (memory information)
lsusb  (USB devices)
lspci  (PCI devices)
lsblk  (block devices)

System sensors:
sensors  (temperature, fan speeds)
lm-sensors  (hardware monitoring)

Disk health:
smartctl -a /dev/sda  (SMART disk info)
hdparm -I /dev/sda  (disk parameters)
hdparm -t /dev/sda  (disk speed test)

Device management:
/dev/  (device files)
/proc/  (process and system info)
/sys/  (system information)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system time and timezone?

answer_side.text_content:
Time and timezone management:

System time:
date  (show current date/time)
date -s "2025-01-01 12:00:00"  (set date/time)
hwclock  (hardware clock)
hwclock --systohc  (sync system to hardware clock)

Timezone:
timedatectl  (show time settings)
timedatectl set-timezone America/New_York
timedatectl list-timezones  (available timezones)
ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/UTC /etc/localtime

NTP synchronization:
timedatectl set-ntp true  (enable NTP)
systemctl status systemd-timesyncd
ntpdate pool.ntp.org  (manual sync)

Time formats:
date +"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"  (custom format)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system automation and scripting?

answer_side.text_content:
System automation:

Script execution:
bash script.sh  (run bash script)
chmod +x script.sh  (make executable)
./script.sh  (execute script)

Scheduling:
crontab -e  (user cron jobs)
sudo crontab -e  (root cron jobs)
at now + 1 hour  (one-time task)
batch  (run when load is low)

Systemd timers:
systemctl list-timers  (active timers)
systemctl enable timer.timer

Process control:
nohup command &  (run in background)
screen -S session_name  (persistent session)
tmux new -s session_name  (terminal multiplexer)
killall process_name  (kill by name)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system locales and internationalization?

answer_side.text_content:
Locale management:

Locale commands:
locale  (show current locale)
locale -a  (available locales)
localectl  (systemd locale control)
localectl list-locales  (available locales)

Set locale:
localectl set-locale LANG=en_US.UTF-8
export LANG=en_US.UTF-8  (temporary)
echo 'LANG=en_US.UTF-8' > /etc/locale.conf

Generate locales:
locale-gen en_US.UTF-8
dpkg-reconfigure locales  (Debian/Ubuntu)

Keyboard layout:
localectl set-keymap us
localectl list-keymaps  (available keymaps)
loadkeys us  (temporary keyboard change)

information_side.text_content: What are the key commands for system security auditing?

answer_side.text_content:
Security auditing:

System integrity:
rkhunter --check  (rootkit detection)
chkrootkit  (rootkit checker)
lynis audit system  (security auditing)
tripwire --check  (file integrity monitoring)

Access monitoring:
lastlog  (last login times)
utmpdump /var/log/wtmp  (login records)
who -a  (detailed user info)
w  (who is doing what)

File permissions:
find / -perm -4000 -type f  (find SUID files)
find / -perm -2000 -type f  (find SGID files)
find / -type f -perm 777  (world-writable files)

Process auditing:
lsof  (open files)
fuser /path/to/file  (processes using file)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system quotas and disk usage limits?

answer_side.text_content:
Disk quota management:

Enable quotas:
/etc/fstab: /dev/sda1 /home ext4 defaults,usrquota,grpquota 0 2
mount -o remount /home
quotacheck -cum /home  (create quota files)
quotaon /home  (enable quotas)

Set quotas:
edquota username  (edit user quota)
edquota -g groupname  (edit group quota)
setquota username 100000 110000 1000 1100 /home

Monitor quotas:
quota username  (user quota usage)
repquota /home  (quota report)
quotacheck -avum  (check all quotas)

Quota commands:
quotaoff /home  (disable quotas)
warnquota  (send quota warnings)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system troubleshooting and debugging?

answer_side.text_content:
System troubleshooting:

System diagnosis:
strace command  (trace system calls)
ltrace command  (trace library calls)
gdb program  (GNU debugger)
valgrind program  (memory error detection)

Process debugging:
pstree  (process tree)
lsof -p PID  (files opened by process)
/proc/PID/  (process information)
kill -USR1 PID  (send signal)

System state:
dmesg | tail  (kernel messages)
journalctl -xe  (systemd logs with details)
systemctl --failed  (failed services)
systemctl status service_name

Resource issues:
iotop  (I/O usage by process)
lsof | grep deleted  (deleted but open files)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system containers and virtualization?

answer_side.text_content:
Containerization and virtualization:

Docker commands:
docker ps  (running containers)
docker images  (available images)
docker run -it ubuntu bash  (run interactive container)
docker exec -it container_id bash  (enter container)
docker stop container_id  (stop container)
docker rm container_id  (remove container)

Systemd containers:
machinectl list  (list containers)
systemd-nspawn -D /path/to/container  (spawn container)

Virtualization:
virsh list  (list VMs)
qemu-img create -f qcow2 disk.qcow2 10G  (create disk)
kvm -m 1024 -hda disk.qcow2  (start VM)
vboxmanage list vms  (VirtualBox VMs)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system encryption and cryptography?

answer_side.text_content:
Encryption and cryptography:

Disk encryption (LUKS):
cryptsetup luksFormat /dev/sdb1  (encrypt partition)
cryptsetup luksOpen /dev/sdb1 encrypted_disk  (open)
mount /dev/mapper/encrypted_disk /mnt  (mount)
cryptsetup luksClose encrypted_disk  (close)

File encryption:
gpg --symmetric file.txt  (encrypt file)
gpg --decrypt file.txt.gpg  (decrypt file)
encfs ~/encrypted ~/decrypted  (encrypted filesystem)

SSL/TLS:
openssl genrsa -out private.key 2048  (generate key)
openssl req -new -x509 -key private.key -out cert.pem

Hashing:
sha256sum file.txt  (SHA256 hash)
md5sum file.txt  (MD5 hash)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system archives and compression?

answer_side.text_content:
Archive and compression management:

Tar archives:
tar -czf archive.tar.gz directory/  (create gzip archive)
tar -xzf archive.tar.gz  (extract gzip archive)
tar -cjf archive.tar.bz2 directory/  (create bzip2 archive)
tar -tf archive.tar.gz  (list contents)
tar --exclude='*.log' -czf archive.tar.gz dir/

Compression tools:
gzip file.txt  (compress file)
gunzip file.txt.gz  (decompress)
bzip2 file.txt  (better compression)
bunzip2 file.txt.bz2  (decompress bzip2)
xz file.txt  (best compression)
unxz file.txt.xz  (decompress xz)

Zip archives:
zip -r archive.zip directory/
unzip archive.zip

information_side.text_content: What are the essential commands for system monitoring and alerting?

answer_side.text_content:
System monitoring and alerting:

Real-time monitoring:
watch -n 1 'free -h'  (monitor memory every second)
watch -n 5 'df -h'  (monitor disk space)
glances  (comprehensive system monitor)
bmon  (bandwidth monitor)

System alerts:
mail -s "Alert" admin@example.com < message.txt
logger "Custom log message"  (send to syslog)
wall "System maintenance in 10 minutes"  (broadcast)

Monitoring scripts:
#!/bin/bash
if [ $(df / | tail -1 | awk '{print $5}' | sed 's/%//') -gt 90 ]; then
  echo "Disk space critical" | mail admin@example.com
fi

Notification:
notify-send "Title" "Message"  (desktop notification)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system databases and data stores?

answer_side.text_content:
Database and data store management:

MySQL/MariaDB:
systemctl start mysql  (start service)
mysql -u root -p  (connect to database)
mysqldump database > backup.sql  (backup)
mysql database < backup.sql  (restore)
mysqlcheck --all-databases  (check integrity)

PostgreSQL:
sudo -u postgres psql  (connect as postgres user)
pg_dump database > backup.sql  (backup)
psql database < backup.sql  (restore)
vacuumdb --all  (maintenance)

SQLite:
sqlite3 database.db  (open database)
.backup backup.db  (backup in SQLite)

Redis:
redis-cli  (connect to Redis)
redis-cli BGSAVE  (background save)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system configuration management?

answer_side.text_content:
Configuration management:

Configuration files:
/etc/  (system configuration)
~/.config/  (user configuration)
cp /etc/ssh/sshd_config /etc/ssh/sshd_config.bak  (backup)

Version control:
git init /etc  (version control config)
git add .
git commit -m "Initial config"
etckeeper  (automatic config versioning)

Configuration validation:
nginx -t  (test nginx config)
apache2ctl configtest  (test Apache config)
sshd -t  (test SSH config)
systemctl --dry-run reload service

Template management:
envsubst < template.conf > actual.conf  (environment substitution)
sed 's/OLD/NEW/g' config.template > config.conf

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system capacity planning and resource allocation?

answer_side.text_content:
Capacity planning and resource allocation:

Resource limits:
ulimit -a  (show all limits)
ulimit -n 2048  (set file descriptor limit)
/etc/security/limits.conf  (persistent limits)
user hard nofile 2048

Systemd resource control:
systemctl set-property service.service MemoryLimit=1G
systemctl set-property service.service CPUQuota=50%
systemd-cgtop  (control group resource usage)

Capacity monitoring:
sar -u 1 3600  (CPU usage over 1 hour)
sar -r 1 3600  (memory usage)
sar -d 1 3600  (disk usage)
collectd  (system statistics collection)
munin  (network monitoring)

Resource planning:
free -h && df -h && uptime  (quick resource check)

information_side.text_content: What are the key commands for system disaster recovery?

answer_side.text_content:
Disaster recovery:

System imaging:
dd if=/dev/sda of=/backup/system.img bs=1M  (full disk image)
partclone.ext4 -c -s /dev/sda1 -o sda1.img  (partition clone)
clonezilla  (disk cloning tool)

Bootable rescue:
grub-rescue  (GRUB rescue mode)
chroot /mnt/sysroot  (change root)
mount --bind /proc /mnt/sysroot/proc
mount --bind /sys /mnt/sysroot/sys

Filesystem recovery:
fsck -y /dev/sda1  (force filesystem check)
testdisk  (partition recovery)
ddrescue /dev/sda /backup/recovered.img  (data recovery)

System restore:
rsync -av /backup/ /  (restore from backup)
systemctl rescue  (rescue target)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system compliance and hardening?

answer_side.text_content:
System compliance and hardening:

Security benchmarks:
lynis audit system  (security audit)
openscap xccdf eval profile.xml  (SCAP compliance)
inspec exec profile  (compliance testing)

System hardening:
chmod 700 /root  (secure root directory)
chmod 600 /etc/ssh/sshd_config  (secure SSH config)
find / -perm -002 -type f  (world-writable files)
find / -nouser -o -nogroup  (orphaned files)

SELinux/AppArmor:
getenforce  (SELinux status)
setsebool -P httpd_can_network_connect on
aa-status  (AppArmor status)
aa-enforce /etc/apparmor.d/usr.bin.firefox

Compliance reporting:
auditctl -w /etc/passwd -p wa  (audit file access)
ausearch -f /etc/passwd

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system integration and APIs?

answer_side.text_content:
System integration and APIs:

HTTP clients:
curl -X GET http://api.example.com/data  (GET request)
curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"key":"value"}' url
wget --post-data='data' http://example.com
httpie: http GET api.example.com

System D-Bus:
dbus-send --system --dest=org.freedesktop.systemd1 /org/freedesktop/systemd1
gdbus call --system --dest org.freedesktop.hostname1
busctl list  (list D-Bus services)

Systemd API:
systemctl show unit.service  (unit properties)
systemd-analyze critical-chain  (boot analysis)
machinectl show machine  (container properties)

Process communication:
mkfifo /tmp/mypipe  (named pipe)
echo "data" > /tmp/mypipe &
read data < /tmp/mypipe

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system clustering and high availability?

answer_side.text_content:
Clustering and high availability:

Pacemaker/Corosync:
crm status  (cluster status)
crm configure show  (cluster configuration)
crm resource start resource_name
crm resource stop resource_name
crm node standby node_name  (put node in standby)

Systemd clustering:
systemctl enable --now corosync
systemctl enable --now pacemaker
crm configure property stonith-enabled=false

Failover testing:
crm resource migrate resource_name node2
crm resource unmigrate resource_name

Cluster monitoring:
crm_mon -1  (cluster monitoring)
corosync-quorumtool  (quorum status)
crm_verify -L  (verify configuration)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system migration and deployment?

answer_side.text_content:
System migration and deployment:

System migration:
rsync -avz --progress /source/ user@target:/destination/
scp -r /source/ user@target:/destination/
tar -czf - /source | ssh user@target "cd /dest && tar -xzf -"

Deployment automation:
ansible-playbook -i hosts playbook.yml  (Ansible)
salt '*' state.apply  (SaltStack)
puppet agent --test  (Puppet)
chef-client  (Chef)

Container deployment:
docker build -t app:latest .
docker run -d --name app -p 80:80 app:latest
kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml  (Kubernetes)

Image deployment:
dd if=system.img of=/dev/sdb bs=1M  (restore image)
partclone.restore -s backup.img -o /dev/sdb1

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system DNS and name resolution?

answer_side.text_content:
DNS and name resolution management:

DNS configuration:
/etc/resolv.conf:
nameserver 8.8.8.8
nameserver 1.1.1.1
search example.com

Systemd-resolved:
systemd-resolve --status
systemd-resolve --flush-caches
resolvectl query google.com
resolvectl dns eth0 8.8.8.8

Local name resolution:
/etc/hosts:
192.168.1.10 server.local
192.168.1.20 database.local

DNS server (BIND):
named-checkconf  (check configuration)
named-checkzone example.com /etc/bind/example.com.zone
rndc reload  (reload zones)
rndc flush  (flush cache)

information_side.text_content: What are the essential commands for system patching and updates?

answer_side.text_content:
System patching and updates:

Apt (Debian/Ubuntu):
apt update  (update package lists)
apt list --upgradable  (show available updates)
apt upgrade  (install updates)
apt full-upgrade  (full system upgrade)
apt autoremove  (remove unused packages)

Yum/DNF (Red Hat/CentOS):
yum check-update  (check for updates)
yum update  (install updates)
dnf upgrade  (DNF upgrade)
yum history  (update history)

Update automation:
unattended-upgrades  (automatic security updates)
yum-cron  (automated yum updates)

Kernel updates:
apt install linux-image-generic  (new kernel)
update-grub  (update bootloader)
reboot  (apply kernel updates)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system load balancing and traffic distribution?
What commands help with system certificate and key management?

answer_side.text_content:
Certificate and key management:

SSL certificate operations:
openssl x509 -in cert.pem -text -noout  (view certificate)
openssl x509 -in cert.pem -dates -noout  (check expiry)
openssl verify -CAfile ca.pem cert.pem  (verify certificate)
openssl s_client -connect domain.com:443  (test SSL connection)

Key operations:
openssl rsa -in private.key -check  (verify private key)
openssl rsa -in private.key -pubout  (extract public key)
openssl rsa -in encrypted.key -out decrypted.key  (decrypt key)

Certificate authority:
openssl req -new -x509 -days 365 -key ca.key -out ca.crt
update-ca-certificates  (update system CA store)

Let's Encrypt:
certbot certificates  (list certificates)
certbot renew --dry-run  (test renewal)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system mail and messaging services?

answer_side.text_content:
Mail and messaging services:

Postfix mail server:
postconf -n  (show non-default settings)
postqueue -p  (view mail queue)
postsuper -d ALL  (delete all queued mail)
mailq  (show mail queue)
postmap /etc/postfix/virtual  (update virtual maps)

Mail testing:
echo "Test message" | mail -s "Subject" user@domain.com
telnet localhost 25  (test SMTP)
postfix check  (check configuration)

Dovecot (IMAP/POP3):
doveconf -n  (show configuration)
doveadm user list  (list users)
doveadm mailbox list -u user@domain.com

Mail logs:
tail -f /var/log/mail.log
journalctl -u postfix -f

information_side.text_content: What are the key commands for system resource quotas and limits?

answer_side.text_content:
Resource quotas and limits:

User limits (/etc/security/limits.conf):
username soft nofile 1024
username hard nofile 2048
username soft nproc 256
@group hard memlock 64

Systemd service limits:
systemctl edit service.service
[Service]
LimitNOFILE=2048
LimitNPROC=256
MemoryLimit=1G
CPUQuota=50%

Cgroup limits:
echo 1000000000 > /sys/fs/cgroup/memory/mygroup/memory.limit_in_bytes
echo 1000 > /sys/fs/cgroup/cpu/mygroup/cpu.shares

Runtime limits:
ulimit -n 2048  (file descriptors)
ulimit -u 256  (processes)
ulimit -m 1000000  (memory)
ulimit -t 60  (CPU time)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system web servers and HTTP services?

answer_side.text_content:
Web server management:

Apache HTTP Server:
apache2ctl configtest  (test configuration)
apache2ctl graceful  (graceful restart)
a2ensite site.conf  (enable site)
a2dissite default  (disable site)
a2enmod rewrite  (enable module)
a2dismod module  (disable module)

Nginx:
nginx -t  (test configuration)
nginx -s reload  (reload configuration)
nginx -s stop  (stop server)
systemctl reload nginx

SSL configuration:
openssl dhparam -out /etc/ssl/certs/dhparam.pem 2048
certbot --nginx -d example.com  (Let's Encrypt)

Web server logs:
tail -f /var/log/apache2/access.log
tail -f /var/log/nginx/error.log

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system orchestration and infrastructure as code?

answer_side.text_content:
Orchestration and Infrastructure as Code:

Terraform:
terraform init  (initialize)
terraform plan  (preview changes)
terraform apply  (apply changes)
terraform destroy  (destroy infrastructure)
terraform state list  (list resources)

Ansible:
ansible all -m ping  (test connectivity)
ansible-playbook -i inventory playbook.yml
ansible-vault encrypt secrets.yml
ansible-galaxy install role_name

Docker Compose:
docker-compose up -d  (start services)
docker-compose down  (stop services)
docker-compose logs -f  (follow logs)
docker-compose scale web=3  (scale service)

Kubernetes:
kubectl get pods  (list pods)
kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml
kubectl logs pod_name
kubectl exec -it pod_name bash

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system storage technologies and RAID?

answer_side.text_content:
Storage technologies and RAID:

Software RAID (mdadm):
mdadm --create /dev/md0 --level=1 --raid-devices=2 /dev/sdb1 /dev/sdc1
mdadm --detail /dev/md0  (RAID status)
mdadm --add /dev/md0 /dev/sdd1  (add device)
mdadm --fail /dev/md0 /dev/sdb1  (mark device failed)
mdadm --remove /dev/md0 /dev/sdb1  (remove device)

LVM (Logical Volume Management):
pvcreate /dev/sdb1  (create physical volume)
vgcreate vg01 /dev/sdb1  (create volume group)
lvcreate -L 10G -n lv01 vg01  (create logical volume)
lvextend -L +5G /dev/vg01/lv01  (extend volume)
resize2fs /dev/vg01/lv01  (resize filesystem)

Storage monitoring:
cat /proc/mdstat  (RAID status)
vgdisplay  (volume group info)
lvdisplay  (logical volume info)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system process management and IPC?

answer_side.text_content:
Process management and IPC:

Advanced process control:
pgrep -f process_name  (find process by name)
pkill -TERM process_name  (kill by name)
killall -9 process_name  (force kill all)
fuser -k /path/to/file  (kill processes using file)
lsof +D /directory  (processes using directory)

Process priorities:
chrt -p 1 PID  (set real-time priority)
ionice -c 1 -n 4 -p PID  (set I/O priority)
taskset -p 0x1 PID  (set CPU affinity)

Inter-Process Communication:
ipcs  (show IPC resources)
ipcrm -m shmid  (remove shared memory)
ipcrm -s semid  (remove semaphore)
ipcrm -q msgid  (remove message queue)

Process namespaces:
unshare --pid --fork bash  (new PID namespace)
nsenter -t PID -n -p  (enter namespace)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system device drivers and firmware?

answer_side.text_content:
Device drivers and firmware:

Driver management:
lsmod | grep driver_name  (check if driver loaded)
modprobe driver_name  (load driver)
modprobe -r driver_name  (unload driver)
modinfo driver_name  (driver information)
dmesg | grep -i driver  (driver messages)

Firmware management:
ls /lib/firmware/  (firmware files)
fwupdmgr get-devices  (firmware update daemon)
fwupdmgr refresh  (update firmware database)
fwupdmgr update  (install firmware updates)

Hardware detection:
lshw -short  (hardware summary)
lspci -v  (PCI devices verbose)
lsusb -v  (USB devices verbose)
udevadm info --query=all --name=/dev/sda  (device info)
udevadm monitor  (monitor device events)

Driver troubleshooting:
dmesg | tail -20  (recent kernel messages)
lsmod | wc -l  (number of loaded modules)

information_side.text_content: What are the essential commands for system firewall management?

answer_side.text_content:
Firewall management:

iptables:
iptables -L  (list rules)
iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT  (allow SSH)
iptables -A INPUT -s 192.168.1.0/24 -j ACCEPT  (allow subnet)
iptables -A INPUT -j DROP  (default deny)
iptables-save > /etc/iptables/rules.v4  (save rules)
iptables-restore < /etc/iptables/rules.v4  (restore rules)

UFW (Uncomplicated Firewall):
ufw enable  (enable firewall)
ufw allow 22  (allow port 22)
ufw allow from 192.168.1.0/24  (allow subnet)
ufw deny 80  (deny port 80)
ufw status numbered  (show rules with numbers)
ufw delete 1  (delete rule by number)

firewalld:
firewall-cmd --list-all  (show configuration)
firewall-cmd --add-service=http --permanent
firewall-cmd --reload  (reload rules)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system remote access and SSH?

answer_side.text_content:
Remote access and SSH management:

SSH server configuration (/etc/ssh/sshd_config):
Port 2222  (change default port)
PermitRootLogin no  (disable root login)
PasswordAuthentication no  (key-only auth)
AllowUsers user1 user2  (restrict users)
MaxAuthTries 3  (limit auth attempts)

SSH key management:
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096  (generate key pair)
ssh-copy-id user@server  (copy public key)
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa  (add key to agent)
ssh-agent bash  (start SSH agent)

SSH tunneling:
ssh -L 8080:localhost:80 user@server  (local port forward)
ssh -R 9090:localhost:22 user@server  (remote port forward)
ssh -D 1080 user@server  (SOCKS proxy)

SSH monitoring:
who  (current SSH sessions)
last  (login history)
ssh -v user@server  (verbose connection)

information_side.text_content: What commands help with system power management and ACPI?

answer_side.text_content:
Power management and ACPI:

Power states:
systemctl suspend  (suspend to RAM)
systemctl hibernate  (suspend to disk)
systemctl hybrid-sleep  (hybrid suspend)
poweroff  (shutdown system)
reboot  (restart system)

ACPI information:
acpi -V  (battery and thermal info)
acpi -t  (temperature)
acpi -a  (AC adapter status)
cat /proc/acpi/battery/BAT0/state  (battery state)

CPU frequency scaling:
cpufreq-info  (frequency scaling info)
cpufreq-set -f 1000MHz  (set frequency)
echo performance > /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_governor

Power monitoring:
powertop  (power consumption analyzer)
turbostat  (CPU power and frequency stats)
iostat -x 1  (I/O power impact)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system printing and CUPS?

answer_side.text_content:
Printing and CUPS management:

CUPS administration:
lpadmin -p printer_name -E -v device_uri  (add printer)
lpadmin -d printer_name  (set default printer)
lpadmin -x printer_name  (remove printer)
cupsctl --remote-admin  (enable remote admin)

Print queue management:
lpq  (show print queue)
lprm job_id  (remove print job)
lpc status  (printer status)
lpstat -t  (show all printer info)

Printing commands:
lp file.txt  (print file)
lp -d printer_name file.txt  (print to specific printer)
lp -n 3 file.txt  (print 3 copies)
cancel job_id  (cancel print job)

CUPS logs:
tail -f /var/log/cups/error_log
tail -f /var/log/cups/access_log

Web interface:
http://localhost:631  (CUPS web interface)

information_side.text_content: What are the key commands for system benchmarking and testing?

answer_side.text_content:
System benchmarking and testing:

CPU benchmarks:
sysbench cpu run  (CPU benchmark)
stress --cpu 4 --timeout 60s  (CPU stress test)
yes > /dev/null &  (simple CPU load)

Memory benchmarks:
sysbench memory run  (memory benchmark)
stress --vm 2 --vm-bytes 1G --timeout 60s  (memory stress)
mbw 1024  (memory bandwidth test)

Disk benchmarks:
dd if=/dev/zero of=testfile bs=1G count=1 oflag=direct  (write test)
dd if=testfile of=/dev/null bs=1G iflag=direct  (read test)
iozone -a  (comprehensive I/O test)
fio --name=test --ioengine=libaio --rw=randread --bs=4k --numjobs=4 --size=1G

Network benchmarks:
iperf3 -s  (iperf server)
iperf3 -c server_ip  (iperf client)
ping -c 100 server_ip  (latency test)

information_side.text_content: How do you manage system cross-platform compatibility and emulation?

answer_side.text_content:
Cross-platform compatibility and emulation:

Architecture emulation:
qemu-user-static  (user-mode emulation)
qemu-system-x86_64  (system emulation)
update-binfmts --display  (binary format support)

Docker multi-platform:
docker buildx create --use  (multi-platform builder)
docker buildx build --platform linux/amd64,linux/arm64 .
docker run --platform linux/arm64 image_name

32-bit compatibility:
dpkg --add-architecture i386  (enable 32-bit packages)
apt update && apt install libc6:i386

Wine (Windows compatibility):
wine program.exe  (run Windows program)
winecfg  (Wine configuration)
winetricks  (Wine helper)

File format conversion:
unix2dos file.txt  (Unix to DOS line endings)
dos2unix file.txt  (DOS to Unix line endings)
iconv -f windows-1252 -t utf-8 file.txt

information_side.text_content: What are the essential commands for system documentation and knowledge management?

answer_side.text_content:
Documentation and knowledge management:

System documentation:
man command  (manual pages)
info command  (info documents)
command --help  (help option)
apropos keyword  (search man pages)
whatis command  (brief description)

System information export:
lshw -html > hardware.html  (hardware report)
inxi -Fxz > system_info.txt  (system summary)
systemctl list-units --all > services.txt
df -h > disk_usage.txt

Configuration backup:
tar -czf config_backup.tar.gz /etc /home/user/.config
cp -r /etc /backup/etc_$(date +%Y%m%d)
git init /etc && git add . && git commit -m "Config snapshot"

Documentation tools:
pandoc file.md -o file.pdf  (convert markdown)
rstcheck file.rst  (check reStructuredText)
mkdocs serve  (serve documentation)
sphinx-build -b html source build
